http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Background Tanzania faces high maternal and infant mortality rates, yet key service quality metrics remain underexamined, limiting targeted improvements. Star Rating Assessment (SRA), introduced in 2015, aims to improve primary health care (PHC) quality, including maternal and child health (MCH) services. This study analyses SRA data to assess the prevalence of PHC quality in MCH and its associated factors. Methods Data for this cross-sectional study were collected from November 2021 to March 2022 across 10 regions. The tool used included 12 MCH-related indicators, each comprising specific criteria. Facilities scoring ≥ 80% across these criteria were considered to meet MCH quality standards, which was the primary study outcome. A descriptive analysis of indicator performance was conducted, followed by multivariate logistic regression to assess characteristics associated with achieving the quality standard. Results are reported as adjusted odds ratios (AOR) with 95% confidence intervals (CI). Results A total of 2,583 facilities assessed: 2,189 dispensaries (84.7%), 303 health centres (11.7%), and 91 district-level hospitals (3.5%). Only 280(10.8%) met the MCH quality standards. Maternal audit and review practices aligned with guidelines in 2,057 facilities (79.6%). Moderate adherence was observed for family planning guidelines (48.3%), accurate partogram completion (47.9%), and immunisation standards (46.3%). Major gaps included cervical cancer screening, offered by 199 facilities (7.7%), and essential obstetric medicines, available in 424 facilities (16.4%). Among 394 hospitals and health centres, only 60(15.2%) offered postnatal and essential newborn care with dedicated neonatal and Kangaroo Mother Care spaces. Compliance was higher in public, rural, and higher-level facilities. Nurse availability, functional management, and quality improvement teams were key predictors of MCH quality. Conclusion The quality of MCH services in Tanzania varies widely by facility type, ownership, nurse staffing, and management functionality. Targeted improvements in cervical cancer screening, emergency obstetric care, and newborn care are essential to raise overall MCH service standards. Keywords Maternal and child health Star rating Assessment Primary healthcare Quality of MCH services Tanzania pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025 Introduction Maternal and child health (MCH) is one of the key elements of public health and an essential indicator of healthcare system performance [ 1 3 4 There is increasing evidence that improved health outcomes for maternal and child healthcare are mostly influenced by the quality of care, not just accessibility [ 5 1 3 The quality of MCH services is a crucial factor in attaining both Universal Healthcare (UHC) and SDGs targets on maternal, neonatal and under-5 mortality [ 1 3 1 6 7 2 8 11 12 13 As of 2020, approximately 800 women worldwide succumb to childbirth-related causes each day [ 14 14 5 15 Both structural and process-related obstacles to efficient MCH service delivery have been identified by earlier research conducted in Tanzania and in SSA [ 16 17 18 19 20 The quality of maternal health before conception significantly influences pregnancy outcomes [ 15 15 Complications during childbirth often stem from inadequate emergency obstetric and neonatal care (EmONC). These services, including key signal functions and the proper use of partograms, are critical in preventing maternal and neonatal deaths. Pregnant women may also experience life-threatening conditions like postpartum hemorrhage and pre-eclampsia, which require trained providers and proper clinical tools. The first 28 days after delivery are particularly vulnerable, with many maternal and infant deaths linked to infections and lack of essential care. PHC facilities must implement national guidelines on postnatal and newborn care, including services like Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) [ 21 Research in context Low-quality MCH services are thought to be a bigger challenge than it is estimated because of inadequate statistics in resource-limited countries. Tanzania, as one of these countries, needs more statistics to describe the extent of the difficulties in the quality of MCH services in the areas mentioned above. Word Bank estimates that “238 women die per 100,000 live births due to pregnancy-related causes in Tanzania” by 2020 [ 22 23 Among other initiatives, Tanzania developed a list of MCH indicators to assess and identify areas needing improvement in MCH services. These indicators were formulated considering the aforementioned processes and international standards. They were used to conduct assessments and, rate facilities based on service quality. The MCH indicators were part of a broader set of indicators used to measure the quality of service delivery in PHC facilities under a nationwide quality initiative called “Star Rating Assessment” (SRA). SRA evaluates the quality of the facility across 12 service areas simultaneously [ 24 25 The SRA was one of the initiatives under the Big Result Now program, which was established in 2015 to improve facility performance by enhancing management effectiveness and the quality of health services [ 25 27 The objective of this study was to ascertain the prevalence of PHC facilities achieving the recommended status in the quality of MCH services, as well as the performance of MCH indicators and predictors of MCH service quality. The results are intended to drive specific quality improvement measures at the operational and policy levels as well as to feed continuing health system reforms. Methods Study design This is a cross-sectional study that utilised data collected between November 2021 and March 2022 in 10 out of the 26 regions in the country. Study setting The United Republic of Tanzania is a union of two countries, Tanganyika and Zanzibar. After their union in 1964, the area of Tanganyika became known as Tanzania Mainland and covered 945,500 square kilometres [ 28 According to the National Census 2022, the total population in these 10 regions is about 30% (17,554,018) of the entire country’s population (59,517,754) [ 29 Study population This study includes all PHC facilities in the 10 target regions. These10 regions were purposively samped to ensure each of the 8 zones is represented in this research. Logistics challenges led to one region not being reached, resulting in one zone being unrepresented. However, another region with similar characteristics was substituted in the assessment. In Tanzania, healthcare facilities are divided into the following two main categories: PHC facilities and referral healthcare facilities. PHC facilities account for more than 90% of all healthcare facilities available in the country. Within each region, PHC facilities range from dispensaries and health centres to hospitals at level 1 (council level), in increasing order of expertise [ 30 31 32 31 32 30 33 30 Additional facility characteristics, such as location (urban or rural) and ownership status (private or public), can significantly impact access, management, and service quality. Between November 2021 and March 2022, a SRA was conducted on 2,584 PHC facilities distributed across the 10 regions, as depicted in Fig. 1  Fig. 1 Tanzanian Regions in which Star Rating Assessment was conducted and the respective number of the facilities visited, 2021/22 Inclusion and exclusion criteria MCH indicators and data management The data used in this study are stored in the SRA database, part of the DHIS2 platform managed by the Ministry of Health. In collaboration with the University of Dar es Salaam (DHIS2 Project), the Ministry developed the SRA mobile app, which was used for data collection during the assessment. Data collectors from all levels of the health system in Tanzania were gathered and given one week of training on accurate data collection methods, verification, and analysis. At each facility, the team of assessors included representatives from the council, regional, and national levels to eliminate the possibility of unfair assessment. The collected data underwent quality assessment and were directly entered into DHIS2. The tool used to collect this data was divided into 12 quality assessment areas. Area 11 is called “clinical services” and covers various sub-areas, including MCH. The performance of MCH at each healthcare facility was measured using 12 indicators, as described in Table 1  Table 1 Summary of maternal and child health (MCH) indicators and scoring criteria Indicator Description Scoring criteria 1. For detailed descriptions and scoring methodologies, refer to Appendix 1 *Note: See Appendix 1 Management of study variables and statistical analysis The dependent variable of this study was “quality MCH services”. Each Facility was required to score ≥ 80% points among all allocated indicator score points to meet the quality service criteria for MCH. This cut-off point is provided in the National Guidelines for Recognition of Implementation Status of Quality Improvement Initiatives in Health Facilities [ 34 Furthermore, we described facility-related variables that could influence the performance of MCH indicators. These variables include the location (urban or rural), ownership (public or private), and facility level (hospital/health centre/dispensary). Additionally, we considered other facility variables such as the functionality of the HFMT, the QIT, and the availability of adequate staffing levels for nurses, clinicians, and all healthcare providers. A multivariate logistic regression analysis was conducted to identify the characteristics of PHC facilities associated with this outcome, and adjusted odds ratios (AOR) with 95% confidence intervals (CI) were reported. Results Description of study participants The study included 2,583 healthcare facilities: 2,189 dispensaries (84.7%), 303 health centres (11.7%), and 91 hospitals (3.5%). Nearly four-fifths (2,068, 80.1%) were publicly owned- the rest were private facilities, and approximately the same proportion were based in rural areas (2,139, 82.8%) - with the remaining based in urban areas. Performance of healthcare facilities in MCH indicators Approximately one out of ten (10.8%) of the 280 facilities met the quality assessment scores for MCH services. Considering individual indicators (Fig. 2 Excluding the availability of essential checklists, charts, and protocols for integrated management in pregnancy and childcare in 1,467 facilities (56.8%), the remaining indicators were met by less than half of the facilities as follows: 1,247 facilities (48.3%) followed family planning guidelines, 1,238 facilities (47.9%) accurately completed partograms, immunization services adhered to guidelines in 1,197 facilities (46.3%), and 1,035 facilities (40.1%) followed ANC service guidelines. Additionally, staff received BEmONC or CEmONC training in 995 facilities (38.5%), BEmONC or CEmONC services were provided in 816 facilities (31.6%), and quality child growth monitoring, as per IMCI, was offered in 1,054 facilities (40.8%). Three indicators scored the lowest among others: provision of PNC and essential newborn care (including the utilization of neonatal wards and KMC rooms) in 60 hospitals/health centres (15.2%), cervical cancer screening in 199 facilities (7.7%), and the availability of required medicines and medical supplies for obstetric emergencies in 424 facilities (16.4%). These include lack of access to the relevant guidelines [ 38 44 46 41 42 47 44 48 2 21 Training and onsite clinical mentorship lead to significant positive changes in the performance of MCH services [ 49 50 48 51 48 52 A second major challenge is the inadequate provision of post-natal and essential newborn care services. This was largely due to the lack of neonatal wards and KMC rooms in hospitals and health centres. The presence of well-equipped neonatal wards and KMC rooms can reduce neonatal mortality by 40% in healthcare facilities [ 53 54 55 56 57 37 57 Another finding of concern is that less than 10% of PHC Facilities were providing cancer screening services for women, making this the most MCH-challenging area. Cancer screening is one step towards protecting women from cervical cancer [ 58 60 59 61 62 61 90–70–90 targets by 2030 63 64 In contrast, MPDSR adherence emerged as the most implemented MCH quality indicator, as seen in other countries in SSA [ 65 65 37 66 67 In Tanzania, management and the quality improvement teams directly contribute to initiatives for improving the quality of MCH services and addressing challenges in the quality of MCH services [ 68 70 70 71 The provision of quality emergency obstetric care depends on skilled health attendants working in an environment where drugs and medical supplies are available when needed [ 72 73 76 73 Staffing is another crucial determinant of quality MCH services [ 37 2 77 78 67 79 80 Facility ownership also influenced performance. As seen in other SSA countries [ 37 81 82 81 82 83 84 Facility level and location were also important. Higher-level facilities performed better in providing MCH services compared to lower-level facilities. This has also been demonstrated in various previous studies in Tanzania, where the quality of services improved with the level of the facility [ 70 71 85 88 42 70 71 85 88 A limitation of this study is that we did not interview HCWs specifically about service quality, though they are the primary providers of MCH care. Their perspectives—as well as those of clients and families; could impact how MCH services are delivered [ 37 79 38 Another limitation is that the data were collected during a single-day visits, which may not provide an accurate long-term picture of the facility, especially for consumable commodities like medicines. Conclusion This study highlights critical gaps in the quality of MCH services in PHC facilities in Tanzania. Despite the availability of national guidelines and tools, implementation remains suboptimal, especially in areas such as antenatal care, intrapartum monitoring, emergency obstetric services, postnatal and newborn care, and cervical cancer screening. Key challenges include poor adherence to the available guidelines, inadequate staffing—especially nurses, weak functionality of management and quality improvement teams, shortage of key emergency medicines, and infrastructure deficits such as neonatal wards and KMC rooms. Private facilities, in particular, lag behind government facilities in providing comprehensive MCH services. To address these challenges, we recommend the following policy actions:  i. Reinforce training and clinical mentorship for all MCH service providers, with a focus on guideline adherence, emergency care, and respectful maternity care. ii. Improve functionality of Quality Improvement and management Teams at all levels of the health system to ensure ongoing monitoring, evaluation, and improvement of MCH service delivery. iii. Ensure continuous supply of essential medicines and supplies, particularly those required for managing obstetric emergencies, across all PHC facilities. iv. Scale up infrastructure for newborn care, including functional neonatal wards and KMC rooms. v. Expand cervical cancer screening services and integrate them into routine PHC services to support national targets for cancer prevention and early detection. vi. Address human resource gaps by recruiting and equitably distributing skilled healthcare workers, prioritizing the retention and motivation of nurses, who are central to MCH service delivery. The quality and equality of MCH services in Tanzania may be greatly enhanced by putting these policy initiatives into practice, which will ultimately lower preventable maternal and infant mortality and move the country closer to universal health coverage. Future studies could employ research designs capable of establishing cause-and-effect relationships and incorporate qualitative methods to capture stakeholders’ perspectives on the reasons for facilities’ inadequate adherence to MCH quality standards. Appendix 1. Description and scoring of MCH indicators/variables related to Facility characteristics  Indicator/variable Description and means of scoring Indicator 1: Antenatal care (ANC) services follow guidelines This indicator aimed to determine whether the facility follows ANC guidelines. To assess this, the evaluators asked 3 main questions, each with a possible score of 3 points. The first question was whether routine antenatal services were provided as required. Seven routine services were inquired about in this question, which are: i. Iron supplementation ii. Folic acid supplementation iii. Mebendazole tablets iv. Intermittent preventive treatment (IPT) for malaria v. Tetanus toxoid vaccination vi. Monitoring for hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (checking the antenatal card) vii. Syphilis rapid diagnostic test To verify the above services, the assessor was required to review three ANC visits to ensure that the cards were filled out properly and that the package of services was provided. The cards were selected randomly. There were three possible scores: Yes: 1.00, Partial: 0.50, and No: 0.00. A Yes score was given if the entire package of services was provided and the cards were correctly filled out in all three ANC visits. A Partial score was given if less than the entire package was provided or if the ANC card was incorrectly filled out in one case. A No score was given for less than half of the full package. The second question was whether ANC guidelines, SOPs, checklists, or job aids, including wall charts, were available for reference. The possible scores were Yes: 1.00 and No: 0.00. A Yes score was given if all items were available, and a No score was given if not all items were available. The last question for this indicator was to check if 3 equipment—BP machines, foetoscopes, and adult weighing scales—were available and functioning. The possible scores were Yes: 1.00 and No: 0.00. A Yes score was given if all three items were available and functioning, and a No score was given if one or more items were unavailable for use. Indicator 2: Family planning services follow guidelines The goal of this indicator was to determine whether the family planning services provided adhere to guidelines. To assess this, the evaluators asked three main questions, each with a possible score of 3 points. The first question is whether all family planning methods were offered according to the level of health facility and expertise. The assessor was required to check and review records of issues in the previous week. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00, Partial: 0.50, and No: 0.00. Yes was scored if family planning methods offered include oral contraceptives, injectable contraceptives, condoms, and ovulation methods. Partial was scored if fewer than four methods were offered. No was scored if none of the methods were offered. The second question is whether family planning methods were offered according to the client’s informed choice. This was achieved through exit interviews with three family planning clients to ascertain their informed choice of family planning method. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00 and No: 0.00. Yes was scored if all three clients were offered contraceptives according to informed choice. No was scored if fewer than three clients were offered contraceptives according to informed choice. The final question in this indicator is whether there was any healthcare worker trained in family planning methods. At the dispensary level, any method was considered suitable, while at the health centre and hospital levels, the requirement was for at least 2 healthcare workers to be trained on long-term/permanent family planning methods. Examples of long-term methods include intrauterine devices (IUDs), implants, female sterilization, and vasectomy. Two possible scores were available: Yes:1.00 and No:0.00. Indicator 3: Cervical Cancer screening is provided This indicator included only health centres and hospitals and aimed to determine whether the facility offered cervical cancer screening and treatment services for early cervical lesions. Two possible scores were available: Yes: 1.00 and No: 0.00. Indicator 4: Immunization services follow guidelines The goal of this indicator was to determine if the immunization services provided adhere to guidelines. To assess this, assessors asked four main questions, each with a possible score of 4 points. The first question is whether the national guidelines for child immunization were available for reference. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00, No: 0.00, NA: 1.00. Yes, if the immunization guidelines were seen, No, if not seen, and NA if the private facility does not offer immunization services. The second question is whether any healthcare worker or provider(s) of immunization services received any training in child immunization services in the last two years. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00 (At least one trained), No: 0.00 (None trained), and NA: 1.00 (If the private facility does not offer immunization service). The third question is to check whether cold chain equipment (standard vaccine refrigerator, vaccine carrier, thermometer, fridge, and freezer tag, daily updated temperature chart, and power source) was available and functioning on the day of assessment. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00, No: 0.00, NA: 1.00. Yes, was scored if all items were available and functioning on the day. No, if any item was missing (cold chain not fully functional). NA if the private facility does not offer immunization services. The fourth question is whether the facility had all necessary vaccines (i. BCG, ii. Polio, iii. Measles and Rubella, iv. Pentavalent, v. Rotavirus, vi. Pneumococcal Vaccine (PCV 13), vii. Tetanus Toxoid, viii. Human Papilloma Virus) available and usable on the assessment day. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00, Partial: 0.50, No: 0.00, NA: 1.00. Yes, was scored if all vaccines were available and usable. Partial if one vaccine was unavailable or not usable, and No, if more than one was not available or not usable. NA, if the private facility does not offer immunization services. Indicator 5: The facility is performing B/CEmONC signal functions. The purpose of this indicator was to determine whether the facility could perform Basic Emergency Obstetric and Newborn Care (BEmONC) signal functions (for dispensaries) or CEmONC signal functions (for health centres and hospitals). CEmONC comprises 9 signal functions, including the 7 signal functions of BEmONC. Each signal function was allocated one score, and Yes; 1.00 was scored for each signal function if the facility could provide it to clients on the assessment day. The 7 BEmONC signal functions assessed were: i. Parenteral administration of antibiotics (IV or IM), ii. Parenteral administration of oxytocic (IV or IM), iii. Parenteral administration of anticonvulsant (magnesium sulphate) for hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (IV or IM), iv. Assisted vaginal delivery (vacuum extraction), v. Manual removal of placenta, vi. Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)/ Post Abortal Care (PAC), vii. Neonatal resuscitation/Penguin sucker. The two additional signal functions for CEmONC were: viii. Blood transfusion and ix. Caesarean section. Indicator 6: Provider trained in either Basic or Comprehensive Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care (BEmONC or CEmONC) The indicator aims to determine whether any providers have been trained in B/CEmONC in the past 2 years. Two possible scores were available: Yes: 1.00 and No: 0.00. Indicator 7: Availability of checklists, charts, and protocols for integrated management in pregnancy and childcare (IMPAC) The indicator aims to determine whether the facility has checklists, charts, and protocols for integrated management in pregnancy and childcare. To assess this, the assessors asked three questions, each with one possible score point. The first question is whether checklists, charts, and protocols for the management of pregnancy and childbirth are available. The second question is whether checklists, charts, and protocols for the management of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) are available for reference. The third question is whether checklists, charts, and protocols for the management of pre-eclampsia/eclampsia are available for reference. Indicator 8: correct filling of Partograms for mothers in labour The indicator aims to determine whether partograms for mothers in labour are correctly filled out. Three partograms were selected randomly to check if all variables, such as the name of the client, the opening of the partograph, parity, gestational age, etc., were correctly filled. Possible scores were Yes: 1.00 and No: 0.00. Yes, was scored if all three partograms were filled out correctly, and No, was scored if fewer than three were correctly filled. Indicator 9: Maternal death audits/reviews conducted as per guidelines. The indicator aims to determine whether maternal audits/reviews were conducted and adhered to the MPDSR guidelines. Indicator 10: Availability of medicines and medical supplies for managing obstetric emergencies The indicator aims to determine whether the facility had medicines and medical supplies for obstetric emergencies on the day of assessment. The items checked were: hydralazine, magnesium sulphate, calcium gluconate, and an oxygen concentrator/cylinder. Yes: 1.00 was scored if all items were available; otherwise, No: 0.00. Indicator 11: Post-natal and essential new-born care follow guidelines The indicator aims to determine whether health centres and hospitals provide post-natal and essential newborn care according to guidelines. To assess this, the assessors asked seven main questions at health centres and hospitals, with one additional question specifically for hospitals. The seven questions are: i . Is there a general neonatal ward and a Kangaroo mother care room for pre-term and low birth weight newborn care. ii. Are there job aids, checklists, protocols, and postnatal care (PNC) guidelines for the assessment and management of neonatal conditions. iii. Is there a dedicated person, at the newborn care unit with special training for newborn care? (E.g., essential new-born care, KMC, HBB, Neo Natalie) iv. Are there necessary functional equipment and supplies for newborn care? (Eg; Resuscitation table, Suction machine, Incubators, cPAP machines etc.) v. Is the newborn care offered according to available guidelines, checklists and protocols. vi. Is there a provision of counseling on newborn health issues on discharge vii. Are there antibiotics for neonates with bacterial infection? (E.g: Benzyl Penicillin injection/Ampicillin injection/ Cloxacillin injection, Neonatal Ampiclox syrup, Tetracycline eye ointment, etc.) The eighth question, which was asked only at hospitals, is if other medicines and supplies are important for the care of a sick neonate. Indicator 12: The facility is offering child growth monitoring services according to guidelines 1. Are staff trained to provide quality growth monitoring according to IMCI guidelines? Ask the staff Observe if child growth monitoring services are provided according to guidelines. (Possible Answers; Yes: 1.00 No: 0.00) Yes. At least one member of staff has been trained on IMCI. No. None of the members has been trained on IMCI 2. Are child growth charts filled properly? Check five charts Observe if child growth monitoring services are provided according to guidelines. (Possible Answers; Yes: 1.00 No: 0.00) Yes. All five charts filled properly No. Less than five charts filled properly. 3. Are HIV Exposed Infants (HEI) systematically identified and Early Infant Diagnosis (EID) services provided alongside child growth monitoring? Adequate staffing level for nurses The facility was considered to have an adequate staffing level for nurses if complied with “Tanzanian Staffing Levels for the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare Departments Health Service Facilities Health Training Institutions and Agencies” 89 Adequate staffing level for clinicians The facility was considered to have adequate staffing level for clinicians if complied with “Tanzanian Staffing Levels for the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare Departments Health Service Facilities Health Training Institutions and Agencies” 89 Adequate staffing level for all healthcare providers The facility was considered to have adequate staffing levels for all key healthcare providers if complied with “Tanzanian Staffing Levels for the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare Departments Health Service Facilities Health Training Institutions and Agencies” 89 At the health centre; the list included one Medical Officer, an Assistant Medical Officer, a Clinical Officer/ Assistant Clinical Officer, an Assistant Nursing Officer, nine Nurses, six medical Attendants, a Dental Therapist, a Pharmaceutical Technologist, Laboratory Technologist, Assistant Laboratory Technologist, and Assistant Environmental Health Officer, Assistance Social Welfare Officer, and Medical Recorder as per establishment. At the hospital; the list included six Medical Officers, 12 Assistant Medical Officers, 9 Nursing Officers, 25 Assistant Nursing Officers, 25 Nurses, 33 Medical Attendants, a Dental Officer, Assistant Dental Officer, a Dental Therapist, Pharmacist, two Pharmaceutical Technologists, three Laboratory Technologists, two Assistant Laboratory Technologist, Radiology Scientist, two Radiographer Technologists, two Biomedical Technologists, and three Assistant Environmental Health Officers, Social Welfare Officer, three Nutritionists and three Medical Record Technicians as per establishment. Note: Assistant Clinical Officer Clinical Officer Assistant Medical Officers and Medical Officers are in order of increasing education level from holding a 2 year-certificate in clinical medicine a 3- year diploma in medicine a 3- year diploma in medicine plus extended training and a 5-year degree in clinical medicine plus internship; respectively. 90 Nurses in this part refer to Enrolled Nurses holding certificate level while Assistant Nurse Officers and Nurse Officers are Registered Nurses with an advanced diploma and bachelor’s degree respectively. Functional health facility management team The health facility management team was deemed functional if met the following four criteria: i. There is a Health Facility Management Team (HFMT) ii. The HFMT has been formally appointed, with Terms of Reference iii. The HFMT meets on a regular schedule (schedule of meetings available) iv. HFMT meetings conducted at least monthly and recorded (Minutes are available for HFMT for the past 3 months and evidence that report is sent to higher management level) Functional quality improvement team The health facility quality improvement team was deemed functional if met the following five criteria: i. There is a Quality Improvement Team (QIT) ii. The QIT meets on a regular schedule (Schedule of meetings available) iii. QIT meetings are conducted at least quarterly, and recorded (Minutes are available for QIT for the past 3 months and evidence that report is sent to higher management level) iv. If QIT conducts and reports internal (self-) assessment on the quality of services at least quarterly (Report of internal quality assessment available, gaps identified, and quality improvement plans specified for the last quarter) v. There have been documented quality improvement activities at the facility in the past six months Facility’s ownership, Facility’s level and Facility’s location These variables are detailed in this manuscript’s “study population” section. Declarations Ethics approval and consent to participate The assessment was considered a programmatic quality improvement activity and did not require formal ethical clearance. However, all standard ethical procedures including voluntary participation, informed consent, and data confidentiality were strictly observed. Prior permission was sought from the Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Elderly and Children (Recently renamed as Ministry of Health) before use of the dataset. The Ministry of Health is a custodian of Health Management Information Systems data including the SRA database. Ethical clearance is not necessary for this type of a study because data were collected in the course of implementing an initiative by the government and hence this analysis aims to give feedback on prevailing circumstances after its successful implementation.
